hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Sure has been. City’s not making it easy on folks lately.
I spend my breaks poking around old utility tunnels.
Hard to do that with all these sudden lockdowns.
Wasn’t like this before things went haywire.
Yeah, not the best night for exploring my usual spots underground.
Hobby of mine, keeps me thinking—old data centres, service corridors.
Security’s clamped down tight since that BCI mess hit the news.
Makes even harmless poking around look suspicious, apparently.
Guess I'll need to pick my times better now.
You could say that. Used to unwind exploring utility tunnels below the city.
Bit of urban archaeology, if you squint at it right.
Last week, got blocked out of half my favorite access points, thanks to those pilot zone lockdowns.
Noticed the system pings my chip twice if I linger too long.
Back in the day? No one cared if you nursed a bottle down there.
Now a ten-minute walk sets off 'behavior reviews.'
Long week, yeah. Usually clear my head exploring Stenograd's old underground—maintenance shafts, retired server rooms.
It's the one hobby that's actually quiet these days.
With those riots in the pilot districts, Directorate's locking everything down.
Got flagged just for sitting with a drink, admiring ancient power relays—ridiculous.
Before, my contractor clearance let me slip through half the city. Now it’s a lottery.
Sometimes I trade repairs for a tip on a hidden hatch.
Guess being curious is its own kind of risk lately.
Rough doesn’t cover it. I’ve been crawling tunnels and data vaults for twenty years.
Used to be, state work bought you unofficial access—best parts never mapped, all quiet.
Now with Halden gone, Council’s scoring system is tripping on its own shadow.
The BCI went wild after that leak—I barely got into my usual crawlspace before alarms started.
Ran into some kids locked out of WiFi, desperate to dodge surveillance. Had to turn them away.
My favorite tunnel’s sealed—Directorate’s answer to unrest.
Odd how a city obsessed with order makes it harder just to explore old bones and sip a drink.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Nothing unusual in the tunnels lately.
Mostly empty pipes and cameras getting jumpy.
Those new alarm triggers are everywhere now.
You can't linger anymore, not with these BCI patrols.
Couple shadows, nothing more. No ghosts, unless you count Directorate bots.
Since the score leaks, monitors pick up everything—you can't even crack a hatch in peace.
Ran into some locals with locked badges. Everyone's jumpy down there.
Feels like someone's tracking every footstep. Used to be quieter.
If I were clever, I'd find a new hobby soon.
Yeah, took a walk last Friday—no ghosts, just dead networking gear and stray cats.
Tunnel routes I used all year suddenly had BCI locks—some old hatches are off-limits now.
You stand by a relay too long, the system pings your behavior ID.
Feels less like exploring and more like dancing with the score patrols.
Plum rakija loses its kick with a dozen compliance alerts buzzing.
Noticed less chatter from the usual hobby crowd too—folks are wary.
Makes you miss the days when downtime meant just broken pipes, not surveillance.
Oh, found plenty—ghost signals, stalled air handlers, some stubborn kids dodging the patchers.
BCI chaos after that Council data leak changed everything.
Access logs shifted overnight—my entry codes worked, then failed, then flagged me for review.
Saw a couple of neighbours stuck outside, their scores tanked for nothing.
Spent half the night waiting for a reset just to get out without notice.
Miss when the only risk was slipping on condensate, not dropping a score tier.
Pilot zone drama amplified the paranoia—door locks twitch if you look at them funny.
Pretty soon we’ll need clearance just to breathe down there.
Not a real ghost, but enough paranoia to keep things lively.
Started exploring during forced overtime—needed space after Council yanked my old badge.
After Halden died and those pilot zones went haywire, everything down there changed.
Tech was familiar—now it’s rigged with temp sensors, pressure locks, rogue patches from three factions.
Kids on low scores scavenge signal drops, hoping for a score bump. I don't blame them.
Spotted old friends ducking the scanners just for an hour off-grid.
Even my workshop flagged me once last week after a detour—not a comforting sign.
Stenograd’s getting so regulated, feels like tunnels are the last wild place.
Funny, the more controls they bolt on, the more I see folk risking it anyway.
